qas.question: When did the Council of Trent agree to the corrected calendar?
To what time did the Council require the date of the vernal equinox to be set?
What did mathematicians of the time want to use to set the date of Easter?

answers.text: motions of the sun and moon

qas.question: What method was used instead of computations of the sun and moon?
What plan to the Council of Trent approve in the fifteenth century?
What did the first Council of Nicaea require to be restored to the one set in 325?
What did the first Council of Nicaea require alterations for?
What was sent to mathematicians in the fifteenth century?
What was adopted from the proposal of Moleto

context: The Council of Trent approved a plan in <a0_0>1563<a0_0/> <b5_0>for correcting the calendrical errors<b5_0/>, requiring that the <b6_0>date of the vernal equinox<b6_0/> be restored to that which it held at the time of the First Council of Nicaea in <a1_0>325<a1_0/> and that an alteration to the calendar be designed <b7_0>to prevent future drift.<b7_0/> This would allow for a more consistent and accurate scheduling of the feast of Easter. In 1577, <b8_0>a Compendium<b8_0/> was sent to expert mathematicians outside the reform commission for comments. Some of these experts, including Giambattista Benedetti and Giuseppe Moleto, believed Easter should be computed from the true <a2_0>motions of the sun and moon<a2_0/>, rather than using a <a3_0>tabular method<a3_0/>, but these recommendations were not adopted. <b9_0>The reform<b9_0/> adopted was a modification of a proposal made by the Calabrian doctor <a4_0>Aloysius Lilius<a4_0/> (or Lilio).
